_header: A man that loveth fishing and fowling both
Subjects: lovers, advice to; hunting; allegorical poems
_description: Piers of Fulham’s ‘many praty conceytis in love vnder covert termes off fysshyng and ffowlyng’ — in couplets

BodJam43.First Lines:
A man that lovyth fyscheng & fowlyng botheofte tymes that game
                    schall hym be lothe…
BodJam43.Last Lines:
…hys fryndes game for to leve in peesStroy not ther stewes rob
                    not ther panters
BodJam43.Attributed Title:
Vayn conseytes of folysche love undyr colour of fyscheng and fowlyng (f.
                    3)
BodJam43.Editions:
Hazlitt,  William Carew. 
             Remains of the Early Popular Poetry of England.
         London: J. R. Smith, 1864-6: 2.2-15.

CULLl414.First Lines:
[A] man þat loueþ fisshing & fowlyng boþeOften
                    tymes þat lif shal hym lothe…
CULLl414.Last Lines:
…His frende is game to lyue yn pesStruy no stewes stele no
                    plays
CULLl414.Attributed Title:
A Doctrine of ffisshing and foulyng (f. 173ra); Explicit res
                    Disputandi (f. 174v)

CamTCC599.First Lines:
[A] Man that lovith ffisshyng and fowlyng botheOfte tyme that lyff
                    shall hym be lotheIn See in Ryver in ponde or in pooleOff that craft
                    thowe he knowe the scole…
CamTCC599.Last Lines:
…An erbe is cause off all this RageIn oure tonge called
                    Culrage

CamTCC599.Attributed Title:
Loo worshipfull Sirs here after ffolleweth a gentylmanly Tretyse full
                    convenyent for contemplatiff Lovers to rede and vnderstond made by a noble
                    clerke Piers of ffulham sum tyme vssher of Venus scole whiche hath brieflye
                    compyled many praty conceytis in love vnder covert termes off ffysshyng and
                    ffowlyng (f. 240)
